author: HCAndersen
text: "WHENEVER a good child dies, an angel of God comes down from heaven, takes the dead child in his arms, spreads out his great white wings, and flies with him over all the places which the child had loved during his life.

author: HCAndersen
text: Then he gathers a large handful of flowers, which he carries up to the Almighty, that they may bloom more brightly in heaven than they do on earth.

author: HCAndersen
text: And the Almighty presses the flowers to His heart, but He kisses the flower that pleases Him best, and it receives a voice, and is able to join the song of the chorus of bliss."

author: HCAndersen
text: These words were spoken by an angel of God, as he carried a dead child up to heaven, and the child listened as if in a dream.

author: HCAndersen
text: Then they passed over well-known spots, where the little one had often played, and through beautiful gardens full of lovely flowers.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Which of these shall we take with us to heaven to be transplanted there?" asked the angel.

author: HCAndersen
text: Close by grew a slender, beautiful, rose-bush, but some wicked hand had broken the stem, and the half-opened rosebuds hung faded and withered on the trailing branches.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Poor rose-bush!" said the child, "let us take it with us to heaven, that it may bloom above in God's garden."

author: HCAndersen
text: The angel took up the rose-bush; then he kissed the child, and the little one half opened his eyes.

author: HCAndersen
text: The angel gathered also some beautiful flowers, as well as a few humble buttercups and heart's-ease.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Now we have flowers enough," said the child; but the angel only nodded, he did not fly upward to heaven.

author: HCAndersen
text: It was night, and quite still in the great town.

author: HCAndersen
text: Here they remained, and the angel hovered over a small, narrow street, in which lay a large heap of straw, ashes, and sweepings from the houses of people who had removed.

author: HCAndersen
text: There lay fragments of plates, pieces of plaster, rags, old hats, and other rubbish not pleasant to see.

author: HCAndersen
text: Amidst all this confusion, the angel pointed to the pieces of a broken flower-pot, and to a lump of earth which had fallen out of it.

author: HCAndersen
text: The earth had been kept from falling to pieces by the roots of a withered field-flower, which had been thrown amongst the rubbish.

author: HCAndersen
text: "We will take this with us," said the angel, "I will tell you why as we fly along."

author: HCAndersen
text: And as they flew the angel related the history.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Down in that narrow lane, in a low cellar, lived a poor sick boy; he had been afflicted from his childhood, and even in his best days he could just manage to walk up and down the room on crutches once or twice, but no more.

author: HCAndersen
text: During some days in summer, the sunbeams would lie on the floor of the cellar for about half an hour.

author: HCAndersen
text: In this spot the poor sick boy would sit warming himself in the sunshine, and watching the red blood through his delicate fingers as he held them before his face.

author: HCAndersen
text: Then he would say he had been out, yet he knew nothing of the green forest in its spring verdure, till a neighbor's son brought him a green bough from a beech-tree.

author: HCAndersen
text: This he would place over his head, and fancy that he was in the beech-wood while the sun shone, and the birds carolled gayly.

author: HCAndersen
text: One spring day the neighbor's boy brought him some field-flowers, and among them was one to which the root still adhered.

author: HCAndersen
text: This he carefully planted in a flower-pot, and placed in a window-seat near his bed.

author: HCAndersen
text: And the flower had been planted by a fortunate hand, for it grew, put forth fresh shoots, and blossomed every year.

author: HCAndersen
text: It became a splendid flower-garden to the sick boy, and his little treasure upon earth.

author: HCAndersen
text: He watered it, and cherished it, and took care it should have the benefit of every sunbeam that found its way into the cellar, from the earliest morning ray to the evening sunset.

author: HCAndersen
text: The flower entwined itself even in his dreams- for him it bloomed, for him spread its perfume.

author: HCAndersen
text: And it gladdened his eyes, and to the flower he turned, even in death, when the Lord called him.

author: HCAndersen
text: He has been one year with God.

author: HCAndersen
text: During that time the flower has stood in the window, withered and forgotten, till at length cast out among the sweepings into the street, on the day of the lodgers' removal.

author: HCAndersen
text: And this poor flower, withered and faded as it is, we have added to our nosegay, because it gave more real joy than the most beautiful flower in the garden of a queen."

author: HCAndersen
text: "But how do you know all this?" asked the child whom the angel was carrying to heaven.

author: HCAndersen
text: "I know it," said the angel, "because I myself was the poor sick boy who walked upon crutches, and I know my own flower well."

author: HCAndersen
text: Then the child opened his eyes and looked into the glorious happy face of the angel, and at the same moment they found themselves in that heavenly home where all is happiness and joy.

author: HCAndersen
text: And God pressed the dead child to His heart, and wings were given him so that he could fly with the angel, hand in hand.

author: HCAndersen
text: Then the Almighty pressed all the flowers to His heart; but He kissed the withered field-flower, and it received a voice.

author: HCAndersen
text: Then it joined in the song of the angels, who surrounded the throne, some near, and others in a distant circle, but all equally happy.

author: HCAndersen
text: They all joined in the chorus of praise, both great and small,- the good, happy child, and the poor field-flower, that once lay withered and cast away on a heap of rubbish in a narrow, dark street.
